text.p: This is how major world bond markets were trading in late European business on Wednesday.

GERMANY - Bund futures fall back from early gains but were still higher than Tuesday's close after a European Monetary Institute report said most EU states do not now meet conditions for the launch of Europe's currency union. The December Bund future on the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (LIFFE) was trading at 100.36, up 0.24 from Tuesday's settlement price.

BRITAIN - Gilts recovered to close up having wobbled after the Bank of England said rates needed to head higher still and inflation would miss its target. With Italian and UK bonds now level pegging, analysts said gilts must be a buy soon. The December long gilt future on LIFFE was trading at 109-14/32, up 4/32 from Tuesday's settlement price.

FRANCE - December bond future resisted profit-taking to settle at a new high, buoyed by the U.S. election and favourable EMU forecasts. The December Notional bond future on the MATIF in Paris settled at 127.36 up 0.40 from Tuesday's settlement price.

ITALY - Italian bonds, futures rein in early enthusiasm, falling from earlier record peak on Dec LIF contract of 126.43. Traders said there some profit-taking after the big gains of the last two days. The EMI said Germany, France and Italy must make sustained efforts to meet the criteria for EMU. The European Union sees Italy's deficit/GDP ratio at 3.3 pct in 1997 but may fall further. The December bond future on LIFFE was trading at 125.61 up 0.01 from Tuesday's settlement price.

UNITED STATES - U.S. Treasuries pared losses to trade little changed. Feeling improves, but volatily remains ahead of 10-year sale. Heavy buying by a hedge fund seen as the main reason of rebound. The December Treasury bond future on the Chicago Board of Trade was trading at 113-29/32, up 4/32 from Tuesday's settlement price. The long bond was quoted to yield 6.58 percent.

JAPAN - The key December Japanese Government Bonds (JGB) contract dived on corrective selling after recent aggressive advances and hedge-selling by investors. Dealers and investors detected a shortening average maturity of bond portfolios, accentuating losses in the longer-end. The six-month T-Bill auction produced an average rate of 0.375 pct.In after hours trading the December future on LIFFE was trading at 125.72, down 0.60 from Tuesday's settlement price on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

EUROBONDS - Activity picked up quickly after Tuesday's relative hiatus. Issuance continued to be varied, with a broad spread of currencies and structures. Looking ahead, Korea Development Bank was expected to launch its planned $500 million global bond on Thursday. Mexico was also due with a 500 billion lire five-year FRN via Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
